title: [FEATURE] Split the SkiaSharp package into separate NativeAssets packages
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The download and install of SkiaSharp is potentially an issue with about 100MB of native files to pull down.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The installation of SkiaSharp should only pull down the native assets that are actually required. If I install a package into Xamarin.iOS, don't pull down macOS, UWP, Android, and all the rest. 8MB is better than 100MB

comments.author: mattleibow
comments.body:
I have been thinking about this and was all ready to go with some work, but then it occurred to me... Is this really worth it?

**Pros:**
 - smaller NuGet package
 - faster download

**Cons:**
 - extra work / maintenance (I have to create a .targets file for each package as only netcoreapp is automatic)
 - more packages
 - potential for mismatched package versions
 - potential for duplicated assets (macOS is both used on netcoreapp and xamarinmac)

Size is just a download number and has no relevance to the final app, or any relevance at all.

Any opinions?

comments.author: acuntex
comments.body:
The big Nuget Package might be a problem.

But normally this nuget package gets loaded on a developer machine with internet access and is cached.

I would rather put energy in somehow reducing the size of the native libraries (e.g. libSkiaSharp.so). libSkiaSharp.so on Android is 6.6MB which is very much on a mobile device.

If only a small feature is used, you still have to include the whole library.

comments.author: mattleibow
comments.body: Finally reached a point where the package got too big to be viable. Now we got smaller packages with SkiaSharp at <5MB (mostly xml docs) and <15MB for each asset package. UWP is a bit bigger at 18MB because it has ANGLE adn watchOS has bitcode which is pretty huge at 25MB

comments.author: nesc58
comments.body:
@mattleibow Thank you for this lib and splitting the native assets. But I have a few questions: 
What is the reason to reference specific native assets for netstandard? Anyone should have the choice which native assets are required.
I think this is a kind of avoiding breaking changes. For people using SkiaSharp on linux there are breaking change because the extra references are required. So why not cleanup and remove not necessary references and let the user choose which assets are required?

The `SkiaSharp` package for `net462` can reference `SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Win32`
The `SkiaSharp` packages for `netstandard1.3` and `netstandard2.0` should not reference `SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Win32` and not `SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.macOS`.
